reinforcements.similarity: Both address the agent-to-platform trust bridge: works-004 prescribes 'Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming' using Kahneman's priming research, while ds-ui-0902-002 prescribes a personalized post-call landing page MVP. Both require the agent's name, property details, and guest names to appear before any platform branding or registration demand.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-004 evidence: Andreas's call ends with human-to-human promises (email exchange, follow-up). The platform arrives unprimed. ds-ui-0902-002 evidence: Robbie expects personal follow-up from Bryant ('just send it to me and let me see' at 07:10). Both hosts' trust is 100% in the agent, 0% in the platform. Kahneman's priming (works-004) explains WHY the trust gap exists; Lean UX's MVP concept (ds-ui-0902-002) explains HOW to test bridging it. Combined: the trust bridge is now validated by two independent host calls (Andreas and Robbie) and two independent theoretical frameworks (Kahneman's associative priming and Gothelf's hypothesis-driven design). The token-authenticated URL from ds-ui-0902-002 provides the concrete implementation that works-004's priming principle demanded.

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe translating between the host's monthly mental model and the platform's per-night data model. works-006 says 'The platform must perform the translation, not the host' using Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem. ds-ui-0902-005 says 'Accept monthly rent as the primary input and calculate the nightly rate automatically' using Lean UX's outcomes-over-outputs principle.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-006 evidence: Andreas processes pricing as 'first month... broker's fee? One month. Three months. Got it' (3:02-3:16) -- sequential monthly sums. ds-ui-0902-005 evidence: Robbie states '$1,600 a month' (02:22) as a fixed fact. Both hosts think exclusively in monthly terms. Kahneman's evidence (50% of Harvard students fail the bat-and-ball problem) explains why asking hosts to convert monthly-to-nightly is dangerous. Lean UX's outcome focus (ds-ui-0902-005) adds that the outcome is 'host confident in monthly income,' not 'host fills nightly rate field.' This is now the strongest cross-run pattern in the library: three independent host calls (Andreas, Nneka/Brad rates, Robbie) all validate that monthly is the host's native format.

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe single-sum financial display with monthly as the primary format. communicates-002 says 'Show One Total Before Any Breakdown.' ds-ui-0902-005 specifies the dual-format display: '$1,600/month = ~$53/night.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: communicates-002 evidence: Andreas computes a total and says 'Got it.' He never asks for nightly breakdowns. ds-ui-0902-005 evidence: Robbie's anchor is $1,600/month -- any other number triggers distrust. Combined: the single-sum principle from communicates-002 and the dual-format display from ds-ui-0902-005 are complementary. communicates-002 defines the information hierarchy (one total first). ds-ui-0902-005 adds the Lean UX test: 'dual-format pricing will reduce pricing support tickets by 50%.' The combined recommendation is that all pricing screens use a monthly-primary, nightly-secondary display with inline fee disclosure.

reinforcements.similarity: communicates-003 ('Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise') prescribes showing the mechanism before the claim. ds-ui-0902-002 prescribes the personalized landing page that shows specific details (property, guests, rent) before any platform claims or value propositions. Both establish that trust is built through specificity, not assertion.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: communicates-003 evidence: Bryant anchors the payment guarantee in the process (credit check, pre-authorization) before the conclusion ('payment guaranteed'). ds-ui-0902-002 evidence: Robbie's landing page must show Bryant's name, East Village studio, $1,600, and Ariel/Amber before any Split Lease branding or feature claims. Combined insight: the trust credential stack principle applies not just to payment guarantees but to the entire first digital touchpoint -- the platform earns trust by demonstrating knowledge (specific details from the call), not by asserting value ('Join thousands of hosts!').

reinforcements.similarity: Both implement a hesitation-detected retreat mechanism for the listing wizard. The existing element (ds-ui-0900-006, 'Rejection-Then-Retreat Listing Simplifier') uses Cialdini's rejection-then-retreat technique. The new element (behaves-0902-003) uses Lean UX's permission-to-fail and small-batch-size principles. Both: (1) detect host stalling, (2) dim the full wizard, (3) offer a simplified 2-3 field alternative, (4) preserve progress, (5) provide a path back to the full version.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Cialdini's rejection-then-retreat predicts that a large request rejected increases acceptance of a smaller request. New evidence: Robbie's 'just send it to me and let me see' (07:10) is a verbal retreat -- he requests a lower-commitment engagement mode. Lean UX's small-batch principle justifies the retreat as accepting the minimum viable input. Combined: two independent theoretical frameworks (Cialdini's social influence, Gothelf's Lean UX) and two independent host behaviors (wizard abandonment patterns from Sherene's run, Robbie's verbal retreat) all converge on the same pattern. This is now one of the most strongly validated interaction patterns in the library.

reinforcements.similarity: works-001 ('System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition') prescribes that every phase transition must pass System 1's automatic assessment through visual consistency and familiar language. ds-ui-0902-001 ('Hypothesis-Test Every Payment Comprehension Touchpoint') prescribes that every payment explanation at every phase transition must be treated as a testable hypothesis. Both address the same problem (comprehension failure at phase transitions) but from different angles: works-001 from cognitive psychology (System 1/System 2), ds-ui-0902-001 from Lean UX (hypothesis testing).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-001 evidence: System 1 evaluates new contexts by searching for familiar anchors. Phase transitions fail when the first impression is unfamiliar. ds-ui-0902-001 evidence: Robbie's three re-asks about payment timing (03:17, 04:06, 06:14) show that the verbal explanation failed as a hypothesis at the evaluation phase transition. Combined: System 1 trust gates and Lean UX hypothesis testing are complementary. System 1 theory explains WHY payment explanations fail at transitions (the new context triggers unfamiliarity detection). Lean UX explains HOW to fix it (build a visual timeline MVP and test whether it achieves comprehension). Together they prescribe: at every phase transition where payment is mentioned, present the visual payment timeline first (satisfying System 1's need for a familiar anchor) and measure whether the host re-asks (validating the Lean UX hypothesis).

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe a listing import path that accepts existing content instead of demanding re-creation. ds-ui-1000-007 ('Listing Import Confirmation Flow') implements the verify-and-confirm pattern for hosts with existing listings on other platforms. ds-ui-0902-003 prescribes the same pattern through the Lean UX waste-removal lens, adding the hypothesis: 'import-path hosts will complete listing creation 40% faster.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: ds-ui-1000-007 evidence: designed for 'experienced hosts who already have listings on other platforms,' with check indicators for mapped data and accent highlights for fields needing attention. ds-ui-0902-003 evidence: Robbie offers to share his existing Craigslist listing twice in two minutes (01:42, 02:49). His instinct is reuse, not recreate. Combined: the listing import pattern is now validated by two independent theoretical frameworks (Refactoring UI's 'build the simple version first' in ds-ui-1000-007, and Lean UX's waste removal in ds-ui-0902-003) and by direct host behavior (Robbie's repeated attempts to share his existing listing). The new element adds the Lean UX measurement framework: track time-to-published-listing for import vs. wizard paths.

reinforcements.similarity: communicates-001 ('Anchor-Then-Advance') prescribes opening every screen with what the host already knows before presenting new demands. ds-ui-0902-004 ('Design Onboarding Documents as Standalone Comprehension MVPs') prescribes a plain-language summary that answers the host's three questions before presenting legal documents. Both use the recognition-before-demand pattern.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: communicates-001 evidence: Andreas describes his units fluently from known information. The platform should present this data back as an anchor. ds-ui-0902-004 evidence: Robbie does not know how many agreements exist after a 7-minute call (07:10). The documents must anchor in his three questions (When paid? Who pays? What if missed?) before presenting new legal content. Combined: the anchor-then-advance principle applies to documents as well as screens. The plain-language summary IS the anchor for the onboarding documents -- it reflects what the host already asked about before presenting the legal detail they have never seen.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the retention experience through cumulative value display. ds-ui-0900-007 ('Cumulative Gift Ledger for Retention') shows total earnings, handoffs, and incidents using Cialdini's reciprocity framework. ds-ui-0902-006 ('Measure Outcome Not Output') prescribes proactive payment notifications and a lifetime earnings summary using Lean UX's outcomes-over-outputs principle.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: ds-ui-0900-007 evidence: at renewal time, hosts evaluate based on memory (biased by recency/negativity). The cumulative ledger counters this with objective totals. ds-ui-0902-006 evidence: Robbie's payment anxiety means the retention summary must prove not just that payments were made but that the host never had to worry. Combined: Cialdini's reciprocity (the platform gave you $9,600) and Lean UX's outcome measurement (you felt certain the entire time) are complementary frames for the same retention card. The combined version should show both: total earned (output) AND zero-worry indicators (outcome) -- e.g., '6 of 6 payments on time, 0 support contacts needed.'

reinforcements.similarity: works-002 ('Design for the Depleted User') prescribes smart defaults and save-and-resume for depleted hosts. feels-0902-001 ('Payment Certainty as Continuous Emotional State') prescribes proactive notifications so the host never needs to check. Both reduce the cognitive burden on the host, but works-002 addresses depletion across all phases while feels-0902-001 specifically targets payment anxiety in the active lease.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-002 evidence: Kahneman's ego depletion and the parole judge study show that depleted users default to denial. ds-ui-0902-001/feels-0902-001 evidence: Robbie's three re-asks show he is already depleted during the evaluation call, and his payment anxiety will compound during the active lease. Combined: a depleted host who must actively check payment status is in the worst possible cognitive state to process ambiguous financial information. Proactive notifications (feels-0902-001) are the depletion-aware design (works-002) applied specifically to payment timing.

contradictions.conflict: The new element specifies --primary-purple (#31135D), --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)), and --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) as the core palette. tokens.json specifies a warm green/earth palette: accent (#2d5a3d), bg (#f6f4f0), ink (#1a1714). The font families also diverge: new elements use Inter and DM Sans; tokens.json specifies Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono. These are two entirely different design systems.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The production CSS variables documented in Style-guide.md use the purple palette (Inter, DM Sans, #31135D, rgb(109, 49, 194)). All existing UI elements in the library (ds-ui-* and rb-ui-*) use the purple palette. tokens.json appears to be an earlier or alternative design direction that is not reflected in any implemented element. The production purple palette has overwhelming evidence (27+ runs, 188+ UI elements). tokens.json has zero implemented elements. Production wins decisively.
contradictions.recommendation: Continue using the production purple palette for all new elements. Flag tokens.json for update to match production. This is a known issue documented in MEMORY.md: 'Token drift detected: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) but production uses purple (#31135D).'

contradictions.conflict: communicates-003 ('Trust Credential Stack') prescribes showing process before promise: first the verification mechanism (credit check, pre-authorization), then the guarantee conclusion. communicates-0902-002 (agent landing page) prescribes leading with personal recognition and property details, with the payment guarantee appearing as a badge AFTER the trust signals. The landing page inverts communicates-003's process-then-promise sequence by showing the promise (guarantee badge) as a tertiary element rather than building up to it through process disclosure.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: communicates-003's sequence works for in-platform payment explanations where the host is already engaged and needs to understand HOW the guarantee works. communicates-0902-002's sequence works for the first digital touchpoint where the host needs to RECOGNIZE the context before engaging with any financial content. Both are correct for their respective contexts. The contradiction is resolved by context: the landing page (first touchpoint) uses recognition-first; the payment explanation (within a phase) uses process-first.
contradictions.recommendation: Maintain both patterns with explicit context guidance: on the first digital touchpoint (landing page), lead with recognition (agent name, property, guests) then present the guarantee as a badge. On subsequent payment-specific screens (pricing, proposal, active lease), use the trust credential stack (process > mechanism > guarantee). Document this as a context-dependent application of the same trust principle.

extensions.gap_filled: Language accessibility for non-native English speakers. No existing library element addresses the language barrier as a systematic design constraint. The library assumes English fluency throughout. ds-ui-0902-007 introduces the 8-word sentence rule, visual-alongside-financial-concept requirement, terminology consistency enforcement, and non-native speaker testing methodology. This is the first element to treat language accessibility as a cross-cutting multiplier rather than a per-screen concern.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Robbie's call + Lean UX). Robbie is the only host in the library who is clearly a non-native English speaker. However, the design principles (short sentences, visual communication, terminology consistency) benefit all users and impose no cost on fluent speakers. High confidence that these principles improve comprehension universally; moderate confidence that the specific thresholds (8 words, 5 non-native testers) are correctly calibrated. Needs validation with additional non-native speaker hosts.

extensions.gap_filled: Progressive timeline activation as a real-time state machine. Existing library elements describe the payment timeline as a static visual (communication/visual layers). behaves-0902-001 extends this to a live, state-driven component that activates nodes as real lease events occur, resets monthly, and accumulates proof of promise fulfillment over the lease lifecycle. No existing element treats a visual component as a continuously updating trust-building mechanism.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but the progressive activation pattern is grounded in established interaction design principles (progressive disclosure, state machines, feedback loops). The monthly reset cycle is novel and untested -- it should be validated with hosts during active leases to confirm that resetting nodes 2-4 each month does not trigger anxiety ('why did my progress disappear?'). The reset needs careful copy: 'Month 2 of 3 -- same path, same guarantee.'

extensions.gap_filled: Token-authenticated, registration-free first digital touchpoint. Existing elements (works-004, communicates-003) describe the need to bridge human trust to digital trust but assume the platform requires registration. behaves-0902-002 introduces a unique URL that lets the host view all personalized content without creating an account, deferring registration until after trust is established. This inverts the standard SaaS onboarding pattern (register then personalize) to match Robbie's expectation ('just send it to me and let me see').
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but the pattern (recognition before registration) has strong precedent in consumer product design (e.g., Airbnb showing listings before requiring login, e-commerce showing products before requiring checkout account). The security implications of token-authenticated URLs (link sharing, expiration, data exposure) need technical review.

extensions.gap_filled: Pricing as emotional translation, not just data conversion. Existing elements (works-006, communicates-002) address the mechanical challenge of monthly-to-nightly conversion. feels-0902-005 adds the emotional dimension: showing only a nightly rate without the monthly equivalent is not just confusing -- it is emotionally threatening because it means the host cannot verify their income against their anchor ($1,600). The emotional design principle ('the host should never encounter a number they cannot immediately verify against their anchor') extends the existing pricing pattern from a usability concern to an emotional design constraint.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens for the emotional framing, but the underlying pricing translation pattern is the most strongly validated pattern in the library (3+ independent host calls, 3+ theoretical frameworks). High confidence that the emotional dimension is real -- Robbie's escalating language at 04:06 and 06:14 reveals genuine anxiety, not just confusion.

extensions.gap_filled: Hesitation as a signal for simplification rather than abandonment tracking. Existing library elements measure wizard completion rates as a binary (completed/abandoned). feels-0902-003 reframes abandonment as a design failure, not a user failure, and prescribes measuring retreat acceptance rate as a positive metric (hosts who would have abandoned are now partially engaged). This is the first element to explicitly argue that retreat acceptance should be tracked as a success, not a failure.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens for the emotional framing, but the retreat interaction pattern is validated by two frameworks (Cialdini and Lean UX) and two host behaviors. The specific threshold (45 seconds for hesitation detection) is calibrated from Robbie's call patterns but needs A/B testing with real platform usage data.

new_tokens_flagged: --timeline-node-size (40px standard, 56px final) -- not in tokens.json or Style-guide.md
--price-primary-size (28px) -- semantic alias for monthly income display
token_compliance.recommendation: Add all 13 tokens to the production token system. None conflict with existing tokens -- they are all extensions (new component-level tokens) or semantic aliases (mapping to existing color values). Priority: --timeline-node-size and --timeline-node-glow are needed immediately for the payment timeline MVP. --field-needs-attention-bg should align with the existing --signal-warn-bg pattern. All icon semantic aliases (--icon-action-color, --icon-info-color) should be added as a group to maintain consistency. NOTE: tokens.json itself needs a full overhaul to match production -- it still uses the warm green palette (#2d5a3d) while all production elements use purple (#31135D).

arc_conflicts: The evaluation phase produces anxiety (payment confusion) that the onboarding phase must resolve, but the onboarding materials (documents sent by email) use the same verbal/text format that failed during the call. The plain-language summary (feels-0902-003/communicates-0902-003) is designed to break this cycle, but if the summary is not implemented, the anxiety persists into listing creation, creating a compounding emotional deficit.

The listing creation phase assumes the host feels relief when the import path works, but if the import fails (dead URL, as in Robbie's case), the host may experience frustration instead. The fallback to call data ('We already know your rent from your call with Bryant') must be robust enough to prevent frustration from accumulating.

The proposal management phase requires the host to accept delayed payment (payment after first night, not upon contract signing). This directly conflicts with Robbie's core emotional need (immediate payment certainty). The payment calendar at proposal acceptance is designed to bridge this gap, but if the host's mental model is not corrected by this point, the conflict will cause dropout at the highest-commitment moment.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc for this host profile (traditional landlord, non-native English speaker, payment-anxiety-dominant) follows a descending anxiety curve: high anxiety at evaluation, gradually reducing through onboarding and listing creation as visual/plain-language explanations succeed, reaching a critical test at proposal management (will the host accept delayed payment?), then a long accumulation phase during active lease where each proactive notification deposits into the certainty account. The arc is not a smooth curve -- it has two potential break points: (1) onboarding, where the plain-language summary must succeed where the call failed, and (2) proposal management, where the payment calendar must convert 'I need payment immediately' into 'I can see exactly when every payment arrives.' If both break points are navigated successfully, the active lease and retention phases benefit from compounding certainty. The Lean UX lens adds a meta-layer to this arc: every emotional state is a measurable outcome, not just a feeling to aspire to. Payment anxiety is measured by check frequency and support contacts. Recognition is measured by click-through rates. Retreat effectiveness is measured by partial vs. full abandonment rates.

discovery.note: Only covered by the agent landing page (communicates-0902-002, looks-0902-002, behaves-0902-002, feels-0902-002) plus the language accessibility element. Discovery itself is passive for agent-acquired hosts like Robbie -- the agent finds them, not the other way around. Coverage is appropriate for this acquisition path but does not address organic/self-service discovery.

evaluation.note: The evaluation phase is the most heavily covered because Robbie's call IS the evaluation phase. Payment timeline, trust handoff, plain-language summary, language accessibility, and payment certainty emotion all converge here. This is the phase where the Lean UX hypothesis-testing framework applies most directly.

onboarding.note: Onboarding is the critical bridging phase between the call and the platform. Covered by the personalized landing page, plain-language summary, payment timeline, import-and-verify path, hesitation retreat, language accessibility, and multiple emotional elements. This density is appropriate: onboarding is where the most dropout risk exists for Robbie's profile.

listing_creation.note: The import-and-verify listing path, dual-format pricing, hesitation retreat, and language accessibility provide comprehensive coverage. The Lean UX waste-removal principle is the dominant theme: accept existing work, do not demand re-creation.

pricing.note: Pricing coverage is dense because the monthly-to-nightly translation problem is one of the strongest cross-run patterns in the library. This run adds the Lean UX outcome framing (confidence in monthly income, not nightly rate field completion) and the emotional dimension (pricing as threatening when the anchor is not visible).

proposal_mgmt.note: Proposal management is the second critical break point. Covered by the payment timeline, payment calendar at acceptance, dual-format pricing, proactive notification setup, hesitation retreat, and payment certainty emotion. The core tension (Robbie wants immediate payment, platform provides delayed payment) is addressed but not fully resolved -- this remains the highest-risk phase.

active_lease.note: Active lease coverage focuses on the proactive payment notification cycle, the progressive payment timeline, and dual-format pricing on the Leases page. Less breadth than evaluation/onboarding, but the elements present are highly targeted at Robbie's core need (payment certainty). Gap: no elements address non-payment active lease concerns (guest communication, property maintenance, date changes).

retention.note: Retention covered by the proactive notification cycle (lifetime earnings summary), the payment certainty emotion (cumulative promise fulfillment), and the retention prompt timing. Thin because this run's lens (Robbie's call) does not reach the retention phase -- all retention elements are projections from call behavior. The existing ds-ui-0900-007 (Cumulative Gift Ledger) provides additional coverage from a different theoretical framework.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The L1 elements (works) do not include a specific element for the monthly reset cycle in the payment timeline. behaves-0902-001 introduces a monthly reset where nodes 2-4 return to inactive, but no L1 process pattern governs how the platform handles recurring monthly cycles vs. one-time flows. The payment timeline's monthly behavior should be grounded in a L1 principle about cyclical trust-building processes.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Lean UX's continuous discovery principle applied to monthly payment cycles: each month is a new experiment run where the hypothesis 'proactive notification will preempt payment anxiety' is re-tested. The reset is not a loss of progress -- it is the beginning of a new measurement cycle.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: communicates-0902-003 (plain-language summary) specifies a Q&A format with three questions. But the three questions are derived from Robbie's specific call. Other hosts may have different questions (e.g., 'How long is the lease?' 'Can I choose my guests?'). The L2 information architecture should define a methodology for identifying the host's top 3 questions, not hard-code Robbie's three.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Lean UX's proto-persona methodology: create a 'traditional landlord' proto-persona whose top questions are payment timing, guest identity, and loss protection. Test this persona against the next 5 host calls. If 3+ hosts ask the same three questions, the Q&A is validated. If different questions emerge, iterate the summary.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: looks-0902-004 (import-and-verify listing) specifies a warm-amber tint for fields needing attention (rgba(254, 243, 226, 0.5)). This is not in the existing token system and may conflict with the production signal-warn palette. The visual treatment should be reviewed for consistency with existing warning patterns across the library.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The field-needs-attention state is semantically different from a warning (signal-warn). A warning says 'something is wrong.' The needs-attention state says 'something is incomplete.' Consider a distinct token (--field-incomplete-bg) using a purple tint (rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.05)) instead of amber, to differentiate incompleteness from warning within the purple design system.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: feels-0902-006 (comprehension through simplicity) identifies language as an emotional inclusion barrier but does not specify how to detect whether a host is a non-native speaker without asking them directly. The emotional element should include a detection heuristic (browser language settings, typing speed patterns, call transcript analysis) so the platform can proactively offer simplified language rather than waiting for the host to struggle.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Lean UX's GOOB principle: rather than building detection heuristics, test the plain-language version as the default for ALL hosts. If native speakers do not find it patronizing (measure via satisfaction survey), the simplified version becomes the production default and no detection is needed. The hypothesis: 'plain language is better for everyone, not just non-native speakers.'
